title: Peter Andre defends new role in Michael Jackson musical Thriller
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Peter Andre has confirmed he is set to star in the hit Michael Jackson’s West End musical Thriller, but has been forced to defend the role following the sex abuse allegations against the singer.

Jackson, who died in June 2009, is accused of sexually abusing Wade Robson and James Safechuck when they were young boys in the 90s.

The allegations were made in the Leaving Neverland documentary earlier this year and many have ‘cancelled’ Jackson’s music since then.

Peter, 46, is set to sing in the play for two weeks in the West End musical and says the allegations should be put aside to enjoy the music.

Speaking on Good Morning Britain, Peter said: ‘I’m going to be doing more the Off The Wall era, not really the later stuff. I love that music, the first album I bought was Off The Wall.’

Addressing the serious allegations against the late musician, Peter explained: ‘I have always said that we’ve got to keep the music separate. The reason I say that, one is because if you’re going to go there and say you can’t listen to the music because there’s allegations, do you listen to the music pre any supposed allegations, where do you go with it?

‘Someone was listening to Rihanna the other day and there was a sample of a Michael Jackson song, and she was telling me she was unsure about listening to Michael Jackson. So where do you draw that line?’

Peter will play Jackson in Thriller for two weeks (Picture: Rex

Jackson’s estate have vehemently denied Robson and Safechuck’s allegations on the late singer’s behalf.

Continuing to defend his musical idol, Peter told Kate Garraway and Ben Shephard: ‘This show is about the music.

‘I always have to say that they are allegations.

‘A friend of mine who loved R Kelly as much as they loved Michael Jackson, will not listen to R Kelly because they saw video footage, evidence, whatever the documentary was.’

The Mysterious Girl singer added: ‘I think that might be where the difference is, is this is still based on allegations. It doesn’t mean there’s no truth in it or you can in any way ignore it. But we’re not at that point where we know what happened.

‘I love the music, this is all about the music.’

Good Morning Britain airs weekdays on ITV at 6am.
